text:
In this video, you’ll see how to 
prepare a launch template in AWS
Application Migration Services (MGN).

With this solution, you can configure 
an account-level launch template,

edit default launch settings for Amazon 
Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2)

instances, and verify that settings have been 
applied to servers prior to migration cutover.

From the AWS Application 
Migration Service console,

let’s go to Settings and  
open the Launch template tab.

The Launch template settings determine 
how instances will be launched in MGN.

The default configuration 
defined in the template

will be automatically applied to every 
newly added server for our account.
Let’s edit our launch template.

Note that any changes we make will not 
affect source servers already added to

MGN, but we can modify 
individual server settings if needed.

We’ll retain the default general launch 
settings to Start instance upon launch,

Transfer server tags, and 
Bring your own license.

Next, we’ll configure the 
EC2 Launch Template settings.

Let’s specify the default target subnet 
that will be used to launch our instances.

We have the option to add a security 
group or modify the default instance type.
Let’s leave these settings as is.
We can adjust the EBS volume types,

IOPS and Throughput to increase 
baseline performance as required.

The Map program tagging 
option is for participants in the
Migration Acceleration Program.
Let’s save the template with our changes.
Now let’s navigate to Source servers.

We have a source server that was added to 
MGN after our launch template was modified.
Let’s view the server’s launch settings.
Looking at the EC2 Launch Template section,

we can confirm that the changes we made to 
the default launch template have been applied.

If necessary, we can edit this newly added 
server’s settings individually from here.

You’ve just seen how to prepare a default launch 
template in AWS Application Migration Services.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
